official-title.#text:
Directing the Clerk of the House of
		  Representatives to provide members of the public with Internet access to
		  certain Congressional Research Service publications, and for other
		  purposes.

Public Access to Congressional Research Service Reports

text.#text:
This Act may be cited
			 as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

, a
			 special reference unit within the
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Congressional Research Service

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, offers invaluable
			 research and analysis to Members of Congress on all current and emerging issues
			 of national policy.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
staff of approximately 700 employees, including lawyers,
			 economists, reference librarians, and social, natural, and physical scientists,
			 are governed by requirements for accuracy, objectivity, balance, and
			 nonpartisanship.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Congressional Research Service

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has a responsibility to ensure that Members of Congress have
			 available the best possible information and analysis on which to base the
			 policy decisions the American people have elected them to make.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Congressional Research Service

text.#text: The

It is often
			 burdensome, difficult, and time-consuming for citizens to obtain access to
			 objective and nonpartisan policy analysis on issues affecting their
			 interests.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
documents on legislation and
			 other critical issues before
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Congressional Research Service

It will enhance our democracy to provide
			 citizens with access to unbiased and accurate

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
will empower
			 citizens and enable Members of Congress to become even more effective
			 “representatives” of the public’s concerns and goals.
